stem: The intensive care nurse is reviewing the positioning protocol for a client with ARDS. Based on the documentation in the Positioning & Oxygenation Log, match the intervention with its primary physiological goal.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00: Client (52-year-old male) with septic shock and refractory hypoxemia. FiO2 is 100%.
09:00: P/F ratio is 72. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates heaviest in the posterior zones.
10:00: Client placed in the prone position for 16 hours.
11:00: Post-proning ABG shows PaO2 increase from 58 to 74.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Integumentary: Padded pressure points (face, iliac crest, knees) while in prone.
Respiratory: Coarse crackles noted throughout; decreased breath sounds in lower posterior lobes while supine.

rows.text: Placing the client in the prone position
Maintaining a strictly negative (restrictive) fluid balance

columns.text: Improve V/Q matching by recruiting posterior alveoli
Increase functional residual capacity and prevent atelectasis
Reduce pulmonary edema and capillary leak
Minimize ventilator dyssynchrony and reduce metabolic demand

rationale.correct: Prone positioning (r1) specifically recruits posterior lung segments that are compressed by the heart and weight in the supine position, improving ventilation-perfusion matching (c1). PEEP (r2) is the primary way to prevent alveolar collapse at the end of the breath (c2). Restrictive fluids (r3) minimize the leakage of fluid into the lungs (c3). Paralytics (r4) stop the client from 'fighting' the ventilator (c4).
clinicalPearls: Prone positioning should be maintained for at least 16 hours per day in severe ARDS.
The heaviest part of the 'wet' lung in ARDS is the posterior/dependent zone.
Always pad the face and iliac crests to prevent pressure injury when prone.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that proning is used to help the patient cough.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Proning is purely about OXYGENATION and V/Q matching in a sedated, intubated patient.
